StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: The average concentrations of formic acid in the atmosphere in Albuquerque, NM in summer 1993, winter 1994, and winter 1995 were 8.6, 6.1, and 4.1 ppb, respectively(1). Thirteen samples collected from the atmosphere of southern California in October 1984 contained particulate and gaseous formic acid concentrations ranging from 0.15-2.13 ppb(2). Twenty-six samples collected from the Los Angeles, CA atmosphere in October 1984 contained particulate and gaseous formic acid in concentrations ranging from below the blank to 2.04 ppb(2). Concentrations of gas-phase formic acid in the atmosphere measured during October 1991 in suburban Schenectady, NY ranged from 0.8-2.5 ppb(3). The yearly average concentration of vapor-phase formic acid in the atmosphere in suburban Dayalbagh, Agra, India measured (137 samples) during the summer and winter of 1992-1993 was 1.3 ppb(4). Winter atmospheric measurements of gaseous formic acid collected from two urban sites in the city of Sao Paulo, Brazil in 1999 had concentration ranges of 0.6-19.4 ppb and 1.4-18.4 ppb(5). Formic acid concentrations ranged from 1.9-10.5 ppb during a smog episode in Claremont, CA in September 1985(6).

Reference: (1) Zhang J et al; J Expos Anal Environ Epidem 4: 25-47 (1994)
(2) Reiss R et al; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 45: 811-22 (1995)
(3) Destaillats H et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 4421-4428 (2006)

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: Formic acid was detected in six of six residential houses located in a suburban New Jersey area in the summer of 1992 with an average concentration of 8.77 ppb(1). Fourteen of fourteen samples collected from four residential homes in Boston, Massachusetts during the winter of 1993 and 26 of 26 samples collected in the summer of 1993 contained average formic acid concentrations of 9.8 ppb and 17.8 ppb, respectively(2). Formic acid was identified as an oxidation product relative to ozone for pine-oil based cleaner (70-120% yield), orange oil-based cleaner (50-70% yield), and plug-in air freshener (90-270% yield) household products(3).

Reference: (1) Gaffney JS et al; Environ Sci Technol 31: 3053-61 (1997)
(2) Sanhueza E et al; Atmos Environ 30: 1861-73 (1996)
(3) Singh H et al; J Geophys Res D3 105: 3795-805 (2000)
(4) Altshuller AP; Atmos Environ 17: 2383-427 (1983)
(5) Willey JD, Wilson CA; J Atmos Chem 16: 123-33 (1993)
(6) Kopperud R, Hildemann LM; Environ Sci Technol 39: 707-15 (2005)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: The average concentrations of formic acid in the atmosphere in Socorro, New Mexico in summer 1993, winter 1994, and winter 1995 were 3.7, 4.4, and 1.6 ppb, respectively(1). The average concentration of formic acid in the atmosphere of Calabozo, a savannah climatic region of Venezuela, in 1990 and 1993 during the dry season was 1.32 and 3.28 ppb, respectively, and during the wet season was 1.84 and 0.82 ppb, respectively(2). The average concentration of formic acid in the atmosphere of Los Caracas, a coastal site in Venezuela, in 1993 during the dry season was 0.66 ppb and during the wet season was 0.62 ppb(2). The average concentration of formic acid in the atmosphere of Altos de Pipe, a cloud forest site in Venezuela, in 1993 during the dry season was 1.53 ppb and during the wet season was 0.97 ppb(2). During the 1997 Subsonic Assessment Ozone and Nitrogen Oxide Experiment (SONEX) airborne field campaign over the Atlantic Ocean, formic acid was present in concentrations of 45 parts per trillion in the upper troposphere and 120 parts per trillion in the lower troposphere(3). Concentration of formic acid at various rural and remote sites in Arizona range from a few tenths of a ppb to 3.5 ppb(4). The maximum concentration of formic acid in several forests was 9.8 ppb during a hot, humid summer day in central Pennsylvania(5).

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
